Thai Fish Name: ปลาฉลามกบ
Description: A small nocturnal shark found in Indo-West Pacific coral reefs and tide pools. Adults are brownish while juveniles display distinct dark bands. Classified as Near Threatened, commonly bred in aquariums due to docile nature.
Physical Description: Concave posterior margined dorsal fin, barbels (whiskers), adults brownish with faint bands, juveniles with distinct dark transverse bands and spots, nocturnal behavior
habitat: Coral reefs and tide pools in Indo-West Pacific from Japan to northern Australia

Thai Fish Name: ปลาฉลามวาฬ
Description: The world's largest fish species, reaching up to 18.8m. A gentle filter-feeder that feeds on plankton and small fish in tropical oceans. Classified as Endangered, known for distinctive white spotted pattern on dark grey skin.
Physical Description: Massive size with mouth at front of head containing 300+ rows of tiny teeth and 20 filter pads, dark grey skin with white spots and stripes unique to each individual, thick skin up to 15cm, three prominent ridges along sides
habitat: Open waters of tropical and warm-temperate seas, primarily pelagic in coastal and oceanic habitats

Thai Fish Name: ปลาฉลามลายเสือดาว
Description: A distinctive carpet shark with dark spots on pale background in adults and vertical stripes in juveniles. Nocturnal bottom-dweller that feeds on molluscs and crustaceans. Classified as Endangered due to commercial fishing pressure.
Physical Description: Cylindrical body with five longitudinal ridges, low caudal fin nearly half total length, juveniles have vertical yellow stripes on brown background, adults have dark spots on pale background, small barbels near nostrils
habitat: Coral reefs and sandy flats in tropical Indo-Pacific from intertidal zone to 62m depth

Thai Fish Name: ปลาฉลามลายหินอ่อน
Description: A small nocturnal catshark with extremely slender body inhabiting shallow coral reefs. Features distinctive black and white spotted pattern forming horizontal bars. Classified as Near Threatened due to fishing pressure and habitat degradation.
Physical Description: Very slender cylindrical body, short narrow head, black and white spots on grayish background often forming horizontal dashes, white tips on dorsal fins, white stripe through gill slits, adult males have long thin claspers
habitat: Shallow coral reefs in Indo-West Pacific from Pakistan to New Guinea at depths not exceeding 15m

Thai Fish Name: ปลาฉลามครีบดำ
Description: A fast-swimming requiem shark easily identified by prominent black tips on fins. Common in shallow tropical coral reefs across Indo-Pacific. Active predator with small home ranges and strong site fidelity. Classified as Near Threatened.
Physical Description: Robustly built with streamlined form, short wide rounded snout, moderately large oval eyes, pale grayish-brown above and white below with obvious white band on sides, all fins have distinctive black tips with lighter borders
habitat: Shallow inshore waters of tropical coral reefs in Indo-Pacific, typically only few meters deep with dorsal fin often exposed

Thai Fish Name: ปลาฉลามครีบขาว
Description: A small requiem shark with distinctive white-tipped dorsal and caudal fins. Rests in caves during day and hunts at night. Highly localized with strong site fidelity. Classified as Near Threatened due to overfishing pressure.
Physical Description: Slender body with short broad head, flattened blunt snout with tubular skin flaps beside nostrils, oval eyes with vertical pupils, grayish to brownish above and white below with scattered dark spots, bright white fin tips
habitat: Coral reef habitats in Indo-Pacific, around coral heads and ledges with high vertical relief, clear water at 8-40m depth

Thai Fish Name: ปลาฉลามลายเสือดาว
Description: A houndshark found along Pacific coast of North America with distinctive black saddle-like markings and spots. Forms large schools in bays and estuaries. Active predator foraging on mudflats. Classified as Least Concern.
Physical Description: Moderately stout body with short rounded snout, large oval eyes, unique coloration with prominent black saddles and large black spots on silvery to bronzy gray background, whitish underside
habitat: Muddy or sandy flats in enclosed bays and estuaries along Pacific coast from Oregon to Mexico, most abundant intertidal to 4m depth

Thai Fish Name: ปลากระเบนค้างคาว
Description: A large cartilaginous ray with distinctive flat disk-shaped body and long whip-like tail. Features dark dorsal surface with white spots and venomous stingers. Known for spectacular leaping behavior. Classified as Near Threatened.
Physical Description: Flat disk-shaped body with deep blue or black coloration and white spots on top, white underbelly, distinctive flat snout like duck's bill, long wing-like pectoral fins, tail longer than body with 2-6 venomous spines
habitat: Shallow coastal waters by coral reefs and bays in tropical Atlantic Ocean, swimming freely in open waters often near surface

Thai Fish Name: ปลากระเบนราหู
Description: The largest ray species with triangular pectoral fins and distinctive horn-shaped cephalic fins. Filter-feeder consuming zooplankton and deep-sea organisms. Known for breaching behavior and intelligence. Classified as Vulnerable to extinction.
Physical Description: Broad head with triangular pectoral fins, horn-shaped cephalic fins on either side of mouth, horizontally flattened body, typically black or dark dorsally with pale shoulder markings, white or pale ventrally with distinctive dark markings
habitat: Tropical and subtropical waters worldwide, pelagic species migrating across open oceans, surface waters during day and deeper at night

Thai Fish Name: กระเบนจุดฟ้า
Description: A distinctive stingray with rhomboidal body and bright coloration serving as warning for venomous spines. Dark green with blue spots and white underbelly. Popular in aquaria. Rarely buries in sand unlike most stingrays.
Physical Description: Flat disc-like rhomboid body, dark green coloration with blue spots and light white underbelly, very short and broadly angular snout, bright yellow eyes, very long tail with two venomous spines, spiracles behind eyes
habitat: Sand and mudflats, rocky coral reefs, and seagrass beds in tropical Indo-Pacific waters from Indonesia to Japan and northern Australia, depths 0-90m

Thai Fish Name: ปลากระเบนคาดฟ้า
Description: A beautiful small stingray with electric blue spots on yellowish background and blue tail stripes. Nocturnal feeder following tides onto sandy flats. Hides in caves during day. Popular but challenging in aquarium trade. Classified as Near Threatened.
Physical Description: Oval pectoral fin disc, large protruding eyes, thick depressed tail with deep fin fold underneath, striking coloration of numerous circular neon blue spots on yellowish brown or green background, two blue stripes on tail, bright yellow eyes, white belly
habitat: Coral reefs and adjacent sandy flats in tropical Indo-Pacific from intertidal zone to 30m depth, common in tidal pools and near seagrass beds

Thai Fish Name: ปลากระเบนหัวคันธนู
Description: A rare, heavily built ray with a rounded snout, shark-like fins, and thorny ridges. Found in tropical Indo-Pacific coastal waters, it preys on fish and crustaceans. Critically endangered due to fishing and habitat loss; adapts well to captivity.
Physical Description: Wide thick body, rounded snout, large dorsal and tail fins, W-shaped mouth, thorny ridges on head and back, bluish gray to brown with white spots, black markings over pectoral fins, crescent-shaped caudal fin, grainy dorsal texture.
habitat: Sandy or muddy sea floors near reefs and underwater structures in western Indo-Pacific, 3–90 m depth.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาโรนันหัวเสียม
Description: A ray with primitive features of both sharks and rays, found from central California to the Gulf of California. Mature at 7–8 years, it reaches up to 137 cm. Notable for magnetic particles in vestibular receptors. Conservation is important due to genetic diversity.
Physical Description: Flattened body, elongated snout resembling a shovel, two dorsal fins, shark-like tail, grayish to brown coloration, ventral side pale, large eyes, robust pectoral fins, magnetic particles in vestibular system, advanced visual system.
habitat: Sandy bottoms and shallow coastal waters from central California to Gulf of California.

Thai Fish Name: ปลากบ
Description: A solitary, benthic predator with a globular, extensible body and variable coloration. Uses a lure to ambush prey, often matching its environment. Found in tropical Indo-Pacific lagoons and reefs, associated with sponges. Grows up to 38 cm; carnivorous and aggressive.
Physical Description: Globular extensible body, soft skin with spinules, wartlike protuberances, variable color (grey, black, cream, pink, yellow, red, brown), large prognathous mouth, modified illicium with esca, angled pectoral fins, small eye spots, up to 38 cm.
habitat: Lagoons, sheltered rocky and coral reefs, often near sponges or structures, tropical Indo-Pacific, 1–70 m depth.

Thai Fish Name: ปลากบลายเขียน
Description: A benthic ambush predator with a globular, extensible body and highly variable coloration. Uses a lure to attract prey, often matching sponges or reef backgrounds. Found in Indo-Pacific reefs and lagoons, down to 75 m. Grows up to 30 cm; carnivorous.
Physical Description: Globular extensible body, soft skin with spinules, wart-like protuberances, many ocelli, large prognathous mouth, modified illicium with esca, angled pectoral fins, color ranges from white to black, cream, pink, yellow, red, brown, three eye spots on caudal fin.
habitat: Sheltered rocky and coral reefs, often near sponges, Indo-Pacific, Red Sea to Hawaii, 0–75 m depth (average 15 m).

Thai Fish Name: ปลาไหลมอเรย์หน้าปาน
Description: A tropical marine eel with a crocodilian appearance, found in Indo-Pacific coral reefs. Burrows in sand, ambushing prey with only eyes exposed. Diet includes octopus and fish. Grows up to 120 cm. Used in Chinese medicine; harmless to humans.
Physical Description: Eel-like, cylindrical body; snout very short; jaws elongate; small eyes placed forward; dorsal fin arises well behind pectoral tips; teardrop-shaped pectoral fins; numerous labial cirri; flesh above and behind eye elevated as a ridge; conical teeth; dark spots on head and body.
habitat: Coral reefs, sandy bottoms, lagoons; Indo-Pacific (East Africa, Society Islands, Japan, Australia); depth 0–30 m (most common 0–2 m).

Thai Fish Name: ปลาหลดหินลายตาข่าย
Description: A large, carnivorous moray eel with a serpentine body and honeycomb pattern of black spots on white or yellowish skin. Found in Indo-West Pacific coral reefs, it shelters in crevices by day and hunts fish and cephalopods at night. Can reach 300 cm.
Physical Description: Eel-like, compressed body; white to yellowish background with numerous black spots (honeycomb pattern); spots vary by environment; large mouth; no pectoral fins; dorsal fin runs length of body; aggressive in large adults.
habitat: Outer slopes of coral reefs, crevices; Indo-West Pacific (East Africa, Red Sea, Papua New Guinea, Japan, Great Barrier Reef); depth 1–50 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาไหลมอเรย์หน้าปาน
Description: A medium-sized carnivorous moray eel with a serpentine body, cream to light brown with black spots. Found in Indo-Pacific reefs, lagoons, and harbors, it shelters in crevices by day and hunts fish and crustaceans at night. Can reach 93 cm.
Physical Description: Eel-like, oval cross-section; white cream to light brown body with numerous black spots; head greenish-yellow with black dots, tapered snout, white mouth corners; spots larger in juveniles; dorsal fin runs length of body.
habitat: Protected areas of outer coral reefs, lagoons, harbors; Indo-Pacific (Madagascar to Polynesia, Japan to New Caledonia); depth 0–50 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาไหลมอเรย์ยักษ์
Description: The giant moray is the largest moray eel by mass, reaching up to 3 meters and 30 kg. It is nocturnal, carnivorous, and hunts cooperatively with coral groupers. Widespread in Indo-Pacific coral reefs, it is known to prey on lionfish.
Physical Description: Elongated brownish body, adults with black specks grading into leopard-like spots behind the head, juveniles tan with large black spots, large mouth, no pectoral fins, dorsal fin runs length of body.
habitat: Lagoons and outer slopes of coral reefs, crevices, Indo-Pacific (East Africa, Red Sea, Hawaii, Polynesia, Japan, New Caledonia, Fiji, Austral Islands), 1–50 m depth.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาไหลมอเรย์ตาขาว
Description: The greyface moray is a medium-sized, carnivorous eel reaching up to 66 cm. It is nocturnal and benthic, hunting small fish and crustaceans at night. Widespread in Indo-Pacific, it prefers shallow, turbid lagoons and protected reefs, often sheltering with other morays.
Physical Description: Serpentine body, brown-yellowish background with many small dark spots, head grey to brownish with distinctive white eyes, slender form, no pectoral fins, dorsal fin runs length of body.
habitat: Shallow, turbid lagoons, protected reefs, debris-rich areas, Indo-Pacific (India, Maldives, Polynesia, Japan, Australia, New Caledonia), surface to 35 m depth.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาไหลสวนลายจุด
Description: The spotted garden eel is a slender, colony-forming eel found in Indo-Pacific sandy areas near coral reefs at depths of 7–45 m. It feeds on drifting zooplankton by pointing its mouth into the current. Grows up to 40 cm; lives in burrows.
Physical Description: Slender, elongated body up to 40 cm long and 14 mm diameter, white to pale yellow with numerous small black spots, pointed snout, small mouth, large eyes, tail tapers to a fine point.
habitat: Sandy burrows in colonies near coral reefs, Indo-Pacific (Red Sea, East Africa, Japan, Indonesia, Australia), 7–45 m depth.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาไหลริบบิ้น
Description: The ribbon eel is an elegant, protandric hermaphrodite moray found in Indo-Pacific lagoons and reefs. It displays striking color changes: juveniles are black, males blue, and females yellow. Grows up to 130 cm. Not threatened; popular but challenging in aquariums.
Physical Description: Long, thin body resembling a mythical dragon, high dorsal fin, expanded anterior nostrils, color varies by age and sex (black with yellow dorsal, blue, or yellow), adult males 65–94 cm, females up to 130 cm.
habitat: Sandy burrows, caves, and coral reefs in Indo-Pacific (East Africa, Japan, Australia, French Polynesia), lagoons and reef slopes, 3–60 m depth.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาวัวหางพัด
Description: The scrawled filefish is a medium-sized, shy, diurnal fish found in tropical oceans worldwide. It inhabits lagoons, coral and rocky reefs, and open water. Grows up to 110 cm. Its coloration varies with environment, featuring blue lines, spots, and a broom-like tail.
Physical Description: Elongated oval, strongly compressed body; olive-brown or grey with irregular blue lines and spots, black spots on head; small mouth at pointed snout; no pelvic fin; two dorsal spines (one long, erectile); rounded, fan-like caudal fin; juveniles yellow with black spots.
habitat: Lagoons, coral and rocky reefs, seaweed fields, pinnacles, wrecks, open water; circumtropical (Atlantic, Indian, Pacific Oceans).

Thai Fish Name: ปลาปักเป้ายักษ์แต้มขาว
Description: The white-spotted puffer is a medium to large nocturnal, solitary fish found in Indo-Pacific reefs, lagoons, and tidepools at depths of 3–35 m. It reaches up to 50 cm, is territorial, and feeds on algae, molluscs, sponges, corals, and invertebrates.
Physical Description: Light grey, greyish, or yellowish body with regular white spots; concentric white and dark grey lines radiate around eyes and pectoral fins; ventral side white; dark shoulder; robust, rounded body; small mouth; no pelvic fins.
habitat: Reefs, lagoons, estuaries, tidepools; Indo-Pacific (Red Sea to eastern Pacific), 3–35 m depth.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาปักเป้าหน้าลาย
Description: The map puffer is a medium-sized, solitary, diurnal fish found in tropical Indo-Pacific reefs and lagoons, from the surface to 30 m. It grows up to 65 cm, is toxic, and feeds on benthic invertebrates, sponges, and algae. Notable for its intricate body pattern.
Physical Description: Oval, spherical yet elongated body; whitish background with dense network of black, brown, or greenish broken lines; irradiant lines from eyes; short snout with two pairs of nostrils; terminal mouth with four strong teeth; no pelvic fin or lateral line; small dorsal and anal fins.
habitat: Reef drop-offs, sheltered lagoons, tropical/subtropical Indo-Pacific (Indian Ocean to western Pacific), surface to 30 m depth.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาปักเป้าหน้าหมา
Description: The blackspotted puffer is a small, solitary, territorial fish found in tropical Indo-Pacific reefs and lagoons, from the surface to 25 m. It grows up to 33 cm, is toxic, and feeds on benthic invertebrates, sponges, algae, corals, crustaceans, and mollusks. Coloration is highly variable.
Physical Description: Oval, spherical yet elongated body; variable coloration (grey, brown, blue, yellow, orange, bi-color); dark blotches on skin; dark around eyes and mouth; short snout with two pairs of nostrils; terminal mouth with four strong teeth; no pelvic fin or lateral line; small dorsal and anal fins.
habitat: External reef slopes, lagoons, tropical Indo-Pacific (Indian Ocean to central Pacific, except Red Sea), surface to 25 m depth.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาปักเป้าก้นดำ
Description: The stellate puffer is a large, solitary, diurnal fish found in tropical Indo-Pacific reefs, lagoons, and sandy areas from the surface to 58 m. It grows up to 120 cm, is toxic, and feeds on benthic invertebrates, sponges, algae, corals, crustaceans, and mollusks. Spot size decreases with age.
Physical Description: Oval, spherical, elongated body; prickly skin; white to grey with black spots (spot size inversely proportional to fish size); ventral area clearer; large head, short snout with two pairs of nostrils; terminal mouth with four strong teeth; no pelvic fin or lateral line; small dorsal and anal fins; juveniles yellowish with dark stripes.
habitat: External reef slopes, sheltered lagoons, sandy areas, tropical/subtropical Indo-Pacific (Indian Ocean, Red Sea, Polynesia, Japan, Australia, Lord Howe Island), surface to 58 m depth.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาวัวลายส้ม
Description: A territorial, diurnal triggerfish with striking orange lines on a dark body. Found in Indo-Pacific coral reefs, it is a key predator of burrowing sea urchins, helping maintain reef health. Solitary, aggressive, and omnivorous, reaching up to 30 cm.
Physical Description: Stocky, oval, laterally compressed body; dark brown to green with orange lines; large head; small terminal mouth with strong teeth; three-spined dorsal fin (first spine long, erectile); orange caudal fin; block spot near peduncular spines; sexual dimorphism in snout and size.
habitat: Coral reefs, lagoons, and external reef slopes in Indo-Pacific, Red Sea, East Africa, and Japan; prefers depths of 2–50 m, adults favor rocky/branching coral, juveniles softer substrates.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาวัวมงกุฎ
Description: A striking, solitary triggerfish with bold black and white spots and yellow markings. Found on clear external reef slopes in the Indo-Pacific, it is territorial and aggressive. Feeds on benthic invertebrates; popular but demanding in aquariums. Grows up to 50 cm.
Physical Description: Stocky, oval, laterally compressed body; large head; small terminal mouth with strong teeth; three-spined dorsal fin (first spine long, erectile); black body with large white spots on lower half; yellowish network near dorsal fin; yellow ring around mouth; white stripe under eyes; yellow and black caudal fin; juveniles with small white spots.
habitat: External reef slopes with clear water in tropical/subtropical Indian and western Pacific Oceans; adults to 75 m, juveniles below 20 m near caves/overhangs.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาวัวไททัน
Description: The largest triggerfish in the Indo-Pacific, titan triggerfish is solitary, diurnal, and highly territorial, especially during nesting. It feeds on sea urchins, molluscs, crustaceans, and coral, often stirring up sand and rocks. Can be aggressive toward intruders; grows up to 75 cm.
Physical Description: Robust, oval, laterally compressed body; large head; small terminal mouth with strong teeth; three-spined dorsal fin (first spine long, erectile); greenish to yellowish body with dark bands; prominent moustache-like markings; strong jaws; up to 75 cm long.
habitat: Lagoons and coral reefs throughout Indo-Pacific (except Hawaii), to depths of 50 m; nests in flat sandy areas, highly territorial during breeding.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาปักเป้าหนามทุเรียนครีบจุด
Description: A solitary, nocturnal porcupinefish found in tropical and subtropical seas worldwide. Inflates and raises spines for defense, with tetrodotoxin in organs. Shelters in reefs and caves by day, feeds on sea urchins, gastropods, and crustaceans. Grows up to 91 cm.
Physical Description: Elongated body, spherical head, large protruding eyes, big mouth, large pectoral fins, no pelvic fins, anal and dorsal fins near caudal peduncle, beige to sandy-yellow with dark blotches and small black spots, skin with spines, inflates when threatened.
habitat: Tropical/subtropical oceans globally, including Mediterranean; juveniles pelagic to 20 cm, adults in lagoons, coral/rocky reefs, 1–50 m depth, sheltering under ledges/caves.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาวัวดำ
Description: A dark blue, highly maneuverable triggerfish found in tropical Indo-Pacific reefs and open waters. Noted for its red teeth, lyre-shaped caudal fin, and unique swimming style. Often seen in groups near the surface, feeding on plankton and sponges. Grows up to 50 cm.
Physical Description: Dark blue body, blue-green fins with yellow and light blue trim, lyre-shaped caudal fin with yellow bar, small pectoral fins, retractable dorsal spine, red teeth, streamlined shape, up to 50 cm long.
habitat: Open waters and current-swept seaward reefs in tropical Indo-Pacific, 0–35 m depth; often seen circling in groups near the surface.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาปักเป้ากล่องเหลืองลายจุดดำ
Description: A solitary, box-shaped reef fish found in Indo-Pacific and Atlantic oceans. Juveniles are bright yellow with black spots, fading with age. Feeds on algae, sponges, crustaceans, and mollusks. Releases toxic proteins when stressed; warning coloration deters predators. Grows up to 45 cm.
Physical Description: Box-shaped body; juveniles bright yellow with black spots, adults blue-grey with faded yellow; small mouth; rigid bony carapace; rounded fins; releases toxins from skin; up to 45 cm long.
habitat: Coral and rocky reefs in Pacific, Indian, and SE Atlantic oceans; solitary, found at depths of 1–40 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลากล่องลายจุดขาว
Description: A box-shaped reef fish found in Indo-Pacific reefs at depths of 1–30 m. Males are black with white spots and blue sides with yellow bands; females and juveniles are dark brown to black with white spots. Grows up to 25 cm; feeds on benthic invertebrates.
Physical Description: Box-shaped body; males blackish with white spots, blue sides, yellow bands and spots; females/juveniles dark brown to blackish with white spots; small mouth; rigid bony carapace; rounded fins; up to 25 cm long.
habitat: Coral and rocky reefs in Indian and Pacific Oceans, 1–30 m depth.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาสินสมุทรขอบเหลือง
Description: A large, solitary triggerfish found in Indo-Pacific reefs from the Red Sea to Samoa. Noted for its yellow-edged fins and robust body, it is oviparous and aggressively guards nests. Grows up to 60 cm; may cause ciguatera poisoning if consumed.
Physical Description: Stocky, oval, laterally compressed body; olive to brownish with yellow margins on fins; large head; small terminal mouth with strong teeth; three-spined dorsal fin (first spine long, erectile); yellow facial markings; up to 60 cm long.
habitat: Coral reefs, lagoons, and coastal waters in Indo-Pacific (Red Sea, South Africa, Japan, Indonesia, Philippines, Samoa); found at depths of 2–50 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาสินสมุทรน้ำเงิน
Description: A large, aggressive triggerfish found in Indo-Pacific reefs from the Red Sea to New Caledonia. Noted for its blue and yellow coloration and biting behavior, it feeds on shellfish and crustaceans. Grows up to 55 cm; divers avoid due to territorial nature.
Physical Description: Stocky, oval, laterally compressed body; brown with yellow margins on fins; juveniles yellowish brown with blue wavy lines; large head; small terminal mouth with strong teeth; three-spined dorsal fin (first spine long, erectile); up to 55 cm long.
habitat: Reef-associated, coastal waters, shallow lagoons, and seaward reefs in Indo-Pacific (Red Sea, South Africa, Society Islands, Japan, Australia, New Caledonia); found at depths of 30–50 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาสินสมุทรครึ่งพระจันทร์
Description: A solitary triggerfish found in tropical Indo-West Pacific reefs and lagoons. Noted for its halfmoon-shaped caudal fin and vibrant colors, it feeds on small invertebrates like crustaceans and worms. Grows up to 25 cm; often seen near coral.
Physical Description: Oval, laterally compressed body; brown to grey with yellowish fins; halfmoon-shaped caudal fin; small mouth with strong teeth; blue lines on face; yellow pectoral and caudal fins; up to 25 cm long.
habitat: Seaward reefs and shallow lagoons in tropical Indo-West Pacific; solitary, found near coral at depths of 2–30 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาสิงโตลายม้าลาย
Description: A striking, bottom-dwelling lionfish found in Indo-West Pacific reefs and lagoons. Noted for its orange, white, and black stripes and large fan-like pectoral fins, it has 13 venomous dorsal spines. Grows up to 24 cm; feeds on small crustaceans.
Physical Description: Stocky body with vertical orange, white, and black stripes; large, banded fan-like pectoral fins; 13 tall, quill-like venomous dorsal spines; rounded caudal fin; banded anal and dorsal fins; up to 24 cm long.
habitat: Coral, pebble, and rock bottoms on reef flats, outer reefs, lagoons, and caves in Indo-West Pacific (Red Sea, Indonesia, Australia); found at depths of 1–80 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาสิงโตครีบใส
Description: A nocturnal, carnivorous lionfish found in rocky reefs of the western Indo-Pacific. Noted for its clear, unbanded fins and two white stripes on the caudal peduncle, it has 12–13 venomous dorsal spines. Grows up to 24 cm; feeds on crabs and shrimps.
Physical Description: Reddish-brown body with six vertical dark bands separated by thin white lines; clear, unbanded pectoral and other fins; 12–13 long venomous dorsal spines; two horizontal white stripes on caudal peduncle; up to 24 cm long.
habitat: Rocky reefs, caves, and crevices in western Indo-Pacific (South Africa, Red Sea, Indonesia, Society Islands, Ryukyu Islands, Australia, New Caledonia); found at depths of 1–25 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาสิงโตแดง
Description: A large, venomous lionfish native to Indo-Pacific reefs, now invasive in the Atlantic and Caribbean. Noted for its red and white stripes and long, fan-like spines, it is a voracious nocturnal predator. Grows up to 47 cm; lives about 10 years.
Physical Description: Elongated body with alternating red/maroon/brown and white stripes; large, fan-like venomous spines; long pectoral fins; dorsal, anal, and pelvic spines protrude like a mane; juveniles under 1 cm, adults up to 47 cm.
habitat: Coral reefs, rocky areas, lagoons in Indo-Pacific (native) and Atlantic/Caribbean (invasive); found at depths of 1–50 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาหินเทียม
Description: A venomous, bottom-dwelling scorpionfish found in tropical Indian and Pacific Oceans. Expertly camouflaged among rocks and coral, it ambushes prey and flashes its pectoral fins as a warning. Exhibits biofluorescence; can reach 30 cm.
Physical Description: Broad head with wide mouth, humped back, tapering body; rough skin with conical projections, spines, and tassels; mottled grey, white, and reddish-brown blotches; 12 venomous dorsal spines; large pectoral fins with orange, black, and white blotches; well-camouflaged among stones and corals.
habitat: Seabed among rubble, seaweed-covered rocks, or coralline algae on reef flats, lagoons, and seaward reefs; Indian and Pacific Oceans from Africa and Red Sea to Japan, Hawaii, Australia, and New Caledonia; depths to 70 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาหินหนามพู่
Description: A venomous, carnivorous scorpionfish found in Indian and Pacific Oceans. Noted for its tassels below the jaw and variable coloration, it is well-camouflaged among reefs. Adults reach up to 36 cm; painful if stepped on due to venomous spines.
Physical Description: Broad, bearded head with numerous tassels below jaw; rough, spiny skin; variable coloration (brown, red, yellow, green, mottled); small scales; large pectoral fins; dorsal fin with venomous spines; cryptic appearance among coral and rocks.
habitat: Reef slopes and coral areas in Indian and Pacific Oceans; found at depths of 1–35 m; often in shallow waters where swimmers may encounter them.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาหมอทะเลฟ้าผง
Description: A vibrant, oval-shaped surgeonfish found in tropical Indian Ocean reefs. Noted for its powder blue sides, yellow dorsal fin, and black head, it is herbivorous and territorial. Grows up to 23 cm; prized in aquariums for its striking coloration.
Physical Description: Oval, laterally compressed body; powder blue sides; yellow dorsal fin and caudal base; black head; white mouth, throat, anal and pelvic fins; transparent pectoral fins with yellow reflections; crescent-shaped caudal fin; small, pointed mouth with sharp teeth; surgeon's scalpel at tail base.
habitat: Shallow, clear coastal waters and flat top reefs in tropical Indian Ocean; prefers areas along seaward slopes; always associated with coral reefs.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาการ์ตูนคล้าร์ก
Description: A widely distributed, symbiotic anemonefish found in tropical Indian and Western Pacific reefs. Noted for vivid black, white, and yellow stripes, it lives among sea anemones and exhibits color variation by location, sex, and host. Grows up to 15 cm.
Physical Description: Stocky, oval to rounded body; laterally compressed; vivid black, white, and yellow stripes; two vertical white bands (behind eye, above anus); orange-yellow ventral side; black dorsal; white caudal peduncle; forked caudal fin; snout orange or pinkish; dorsal and caudal fins orange-yellow; color varies by sex, age, and host anemone.
habitat: Sheltered reefs and shallow lagoons in tropical Indian Ocean and Western Pacific; lives in symbiosis with all ten host sea anemone species; most widely distributed anemonefish.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาการ์ตูนมะเขือเทศ
Description: A bright orange-red anemonefish native to Western Pacific reefs from Japan to Indonesia. Noted for its single white head bar outlined in black, it forms symbiotic relationships with anemones. Females are darker; males are smaller and red. Grows up to 14 cm.
Physical Description: Oval, laterally compressed body; bright orange-red overall; single white vertical head bar outlined in black; females darker with blackish sides; males smaller and red; juveniles darker red with two or three white bars; 9–10 dorsal spines, 2 anal spines, 16–18 dorsal soft rays, 13–15 anal soft rays.
habitat: Sheltered reefs and lagoons in Western Pacific (Japan, South China Sea, Malaysia, Indonesia); associated mainly with bubble-tip anemone (Entacmaea quadricolor), sometimes sebae anemone (Heteractis crispa). Territorial and aggressive when mature.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาการ์ตูนส้ม
Description: A small, stocky anemonefish found in Eastern Indian and Western Pacific reefs. Noted for its orange to black coloration and three white bands, it forms symbiotic relationships with sea anemones. Grows up to 11 cm; popular in aquariums and research.
Physical Description: Oval, laterally compressed body; orange to reddish-brown or black; three vertical white bands outlined in black (behind eye, mid-body, caudal peduncle); fins outlined in black; taller dorsal fin (11 spines); females larger than males; up to 11 cm long.
habitat: Outer reef slopes and sheltered lagoons in Eastern Indian Ocean and Western Pacific (Northern Australia, Southeast Asia, Japan); lives in symbiosis with Heteractis magnifica, Stichodactyla gigantea, and Stichodactyla mertensii; found to 15 m depth.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาการ์ตูนชมพู
Description: A small, pink to peach anemonefish with a white dorsal stripe and head bar. Found in Indo-Pacific reefs, it forms symbiotic relationships with several host anemones. Sequential hermaphrodite, primarily feeds on algae, and exhibits strict size-based dominance hierarchy.
Physical Description: Oval, laterally compressed body; pink to peach coloration; white stripe along dorsal ridge; single white head bar behind eye; up to 10 cm; no color variation by sex or location.
habitat: Reef lagoons and outer reef slopes in Indo-Pacific (Northern Australia, Malay Archipelago, Melanesia, Ryukyu Islands, Sumatra); depths 3–65 m; often shares host anemones with other species.

Thai Fish Name: ปลากะพงหัวโหนกเขียว
Description: The largest parrotfish, reaching 1.5 m and 75 kg, with a bulbous forehead and exposed teeth plates. Found in Indian and Pacific reefs, it feeds on algae and live coral, contributing to reef bioerosion. Gregarious, slow-growing, and threatened by overfishing.
Physical Description: Large, robust body; vertical head profile; bulbous forehead; exposed teeth plates; scales cover body except leading edge of head; color shifts from gray with white spots to dark green; up to 1.5 m; no sex-based color change.
habitat: Clear outer lagoons, seaward reefs, and branching coral habitats in Indian and Pacific Oceans (Red Sea to Samoa, Yaeyama Islands to Great Barrier Reef); juveniles in lagoons and seagrass beds; adults to 30 m depth.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาหางเหลืองหลังเหลือง
Description: A small to medium-sized, spindle-shaped fusilier with a bright yellow back and tail, greyish blue sides, and white belly. Found in Indo-Pacific lagoons and reefs, it forms schools and feeds on zooplankton. Diurnal, planktivorous, grows up to 40 cm.
Physical Description: Fusiform body; small, terminal, protrusible mouth; bright yellow zone from forehead to tail including dorsal and caudal fins; greyish blue sides; white belly; deeply forked caudal fin; dorsal fin with 10 spines, 14–15 soft rays; up to 40 cm.
habitat: Mid-water in deep lagoons and near external reefs in tropical Indo-Pacific (African coast to Indonesia); found from surface to 50 m depth; forms schools with other caesionids.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาหางเหลืองจุดทอง
Description: A large, predatory jack with golden spots above the midline, growing up to 1.2 m and 18 kg. Found in Indo-Pacific rocky and coral reefs, it feeds on fish, crustaceans, and cephalopods. Highly valued as a sportfish; forms spawning aggregations.
Physical Description: Elongated, subcylindrical body; steep dorsal profile; mouth beneath eye; silver with golden spots above lateral line; dorsal and anal fins dusky yellow; pectoral and caudal fins olive-yellow; up to 1.2 m; juveniles more ovate, adults more elongated.
habitat: Inshore lagoons, rocky and coral reefs, seagrass beds, and deep sand banks in tropical/subtropical Indo-Pacific (South Africa to Japan, Australia, Palau, Tonga); found to 100 m depth; intolerant of low salinity.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาอินทรีย์ยักษ์
Description: The largest Caranx species, reaching up to 170 cm and 80 kg. An apex predator found in Indo-Pacific reefs, lagoons, estuaries, and offshore atolls. Hunts fish, crustaceans, and cephalopods; known for powerful predation and gamefish status. Populations declining in some regions.
Physical Description: Ovate, moderately compressed body; steep head profile; strong tail scutes; silvery-grey, males may be jet-black; fins light grey to black, sometimes yellowish; forked caudal fin; falcate pectoral fins; up to 170 cm; sexual dimorphism in color above 50 cm.
habitat: Coral and rocky reefs, lagoons, estuaries, embayments, tidal flats, offshore atolls in tropical/subtropical Indo-Pacific (South Africa to Hawaii, Japan, Australia); juveniles in rivers and lakes; adults to depths >80 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาอินทรีย์ครีบน้ำเงิน
Description: A large, predatory jack with electric blue fins and blue-black spots, found in tropical Indo-Pacific reefs, lagoons, and offshore atolls. Hunts fish, cephalopods, and crustaceans; juveniles prefer shallower waters. Popular gamefish, but may cause ciguatera poisoning.
Physical Description: Oblong, compressed body; pointed snout; silvery-brassy upper body fading to white underside; electric blue dorsal, anal, and caudal fins; white pelvic and yellowish pectoral fins; blue-black spots on upper flanks; forked caudal fin; up to 117 cm.
habitat: Bays, lagoons, coral and rocky reefs, sand flats, seagrass meadows, estuaries, and offshore atolls in tropical/subtropical Indo-Pacific (East Africa to Central America, Japan, Australia, Hawaii); juveniles inshore, adults deeper to 183 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาอินทรีย์ตาโต
Description: A large, schooling jack found in tropical Indo-Pacific reefs, bays, and offshore islands. Noted for its nocturnal feeding, dark second dorsal fin with white tip, and small opercular spot. Hunts fish, crustaceans, and cephalopods; juveniles inshore, adults deeper.
Physical Description: Compressed, oblong body; slightly pointed snout; silvery blue above, white below; juveniles with 5–6 dark vertical bars; adults lose bars, show silvery olive to blue-green; dark second dorsal fin with white tip; small dark opercular spot; forked caudal fin; up to 120 cm.
habitat: Coral and rocky reefs, bays, lagoons, estuaries, sandy flats, offshore islands, and seamounts in tropical/subtropical Indo-Pacific (South Africa to California, Ecuador, Japan, Australia, Hawaii); juveniles inshore, adults to 100 m depth.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาเก๋าจุดฟ้า
Description: A medium-sized, territorial grouper found in Indo-Pacific coral reefs. Noted for its dark brown body covered in hundreds of iridescent blue spots, it reaches up to 60 cm. Males defend harems; invasive in Hawaii; popular gamefish and aquarium resident.
Physical Description: Dark brown body with numerous small, dark-edged iridescent blue spots; larger individuals may show 4–6 pale vertical bars on the back half; robust, oval body; large mouth; rounded fins; up to 60 cm long.
habitat: Coral reefs, rocky areas, and lagoons in tropical Indo-Pacific (Red Sea, East Africa, Japan, Australia, Hawaii); prefers coral heads and crevices; invasive in Hawaii; found at depths of 2–40 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาเก๋าปะการัง
Description: A vibrant, predatory grouper found in Indo-Pacific coral reefs, noted for its orange-red body covered in bright blue spots. Reaches up to 50 cm; forms harems, ambushes small fish and crustaceans. Popular in fisheries and aquariums; protogynous hermaphrodite.
Physical Description: Orange-red to reddish brown body with many small bright blue spots on head, body, and fins; rounded, robust body; flat to slightly convex head profile; juveniles orange to yellow with fewer blue spots; up to 50 cm long.
habitat: Clear coastal and offshore coral reefs, caves, and ledges in Indo-Pacific (Red Sea, East Africa, Japan, Australia, Indian Ocean islands, west-central Pacific); prefers exposed areas; found at depths of 2–150 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาผีเสื้อสามเหลี่ยมตะวันออก
Description: A small, territorial butterflyfish found in Indo-West Pacific coral reefs, recognized by alternating cream and grey chevron bars and three dark head stripes. Feeds exclusively on Acropora coral polyps, usually seen in pairs. Not threatened.
Physical Description: Laterally compressed, high-backed body; alternating cream and grey-brown chevron bars; three dark head bars including one through the eye; maximum length 16 cm.
habitat: Seaward and lagoon coral reefs from Indonesia to Fiji, Tonga, southern Japan, New Caledonia, and Australia; prefers areas with abundant Acropora corals.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาผีเสื้อหางแดง
Description: A striking butterflyfish found in Indo-West Pacific reefs, recognized by its brown-black body, white streaks on the head, and bright red tail base. Feeds mainly on coral polyps, usually seen in pairs or small groups. Not threatened.
Physical Description: Laterally compressed, oval body; brown to black with lighter spotted scales; prominent vertical white streak behind eyes, dark stripe over eyes, smaller white stripe in front; bright red tail base, black band, diffuse white tip; up to 18 cm.
habitat: Coral reefs from Persian Gulf and Maldives to Japan, Philippines, and Indonesia; prefers depths of 3–15 m, often near branching corals.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาผีเสื้ออินเดีย
Description: A robust butterflyfish found in Indo-West Pacific reefs, recognized by oblique black lines and yellowish hindparts. Adults are monogamous and territorial, feeding on algae and coral polyps. Juveniles are solitary. Not threatened.
Physical Description: Laterally compressed, oval body; white with two areas of oblique black lines; yellowish hindpart; black vertical bar through eye; yellow caudal fin; up to 20 cm long.
habitat: Coral reefs, rubble, and rocky areas from Maldives, India, Sri Lanka, Andaman Sea to western Indonesia; found at depths of 2–25 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาผีเสื้อลายขีด
Description: A striking butterflyfish found in Indian and Pacific Ocean coral reefs, recognized by curved black bands on a whitish body and yellow-edged black bars through the eye and snout. Feeds exclusively on coral polyps. Not threatened.
Physical Description: Laterally compressed, oval body; whitish or blue-white with curved to oblique black bands; yellow-edged black bar through eye and snout; up to 20 cm long.
habitat: Coral-rich seaward and lagoon reefs from East Africa to Line Islands, Ryukyu Islands, Great Barrier Reef, Micronesia, Galapagos; depths 2–25 m.

Thai Fish Name: กบหลังลายเฉียง
Description: A small butterflyfish found in Indo-Pacific coral reefs, feeding exclusively on coral polyps. Noted for its distinctive stripes and preference for sheltered inshore and lagoon reefs. Grows up to 12 cm.
Physical Description: Laterally compressed, oval body; white with yellowish belly; 7 black vertical stripes on body, 1 on snout; up to 12 cm long.
habitat: Sheltered inshore and lagoon reefs among corals in Indo-Pacific; depth range 3–20 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาผีเสื้อลายลูกไม้
Description: The Latticed Butterflyfish is an uncommon Indo-Pacific species found from Sri Lanka to Tuamotu Islands, north to Japan, south to Great Barrier Reef, and Micronesia. It inhabits areas of rich coral growth in lagoons and protected reef flats and seaward reefs from 1–20 m depth. Feeds on sea anemones, polychaetes, and coral polyps. Grows up to 18 cm.
Physical Description: Yellow body with cross-hatched dark lines on sides; vertical black eyestripe; vertical black line in caudal fin; most common length 15 cm, max 18 cm; belongs to subgenus Rabdophorus.
habitat: Lagoons, protected reef flats, and seaward reefs with rich coral growth in Indo-Pacific; depth range 1–20 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลานโปเลียน
Description: The humphead wrasse is the largest living member of Labridae, found on coral reefs in the Indo-Pacific. Males reach up to 2 m and 190 kg, females are smaller. Noted for thick lips and a prominent forehead hump. Endangered due to overfishing, habitat loss, and trade. Long-lived, slow-breeding, and protected in several regions.
Physical Description: Robust body; thick, fleshy lips; prominent forehead hump; color varies: females red-orange above, males green-blue; juveniles cryptic in dense coral or seagrass; adults up to 2 m, 190 kg.
habitat: Steep coral reef slopes, channels, and lagoon reefs in Indo-Pacific; juveniles in dense coral/seagrass, adults in open reef edges; depth 1–100 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลากะรังหลังค่อม
Description: The humpback grouper (Cromileptes altivelis) is a demersal, solitary, ambush predator found in tropical Indo-West Pacific lagoons and seaward reefs, preferring dead or silty areas. Grows up to 70 cm. Noted for its laterally compressed, high body and elongated snout. Vulnerable due to rarity, overharvesting, and habitat loss; commonly kept in aquaria.
Physical Description: Laterally compressed, high body; concave profile; elongated snout; adults grey to beige with variable dark blotches and small black spots; juveniles white with round black spots, swim head-down; up to 70 cm long.
habitat: Clear lagoons and seaward reefs in tropical Indo-West Pacific; prefers dead or silty areas; depth range 2–40 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลากะรังลายรังผึ้ง
Description: The honeycomb grouper is a small, solitary Indo-Pacific grouper found from South Africa to Pitcairn, Japan, and Lord Howe Island. It reaches up to 32 cm, with a stocky, ocher to light brown body covered in brown hexagonal spots forming a network. Protogynous hermaphrodite, feeds on fish, crabs, shrimps, and cephalopods.
Physical Description: Oval, stocky body; ocher to light brown with small brown hexagons and pale interspaces on irregular darker bands; hexagonal spots on all fins; rounded caudal fin; convex dorsal head profile; globular eyes; lower jaw longer than upper; up to 32 cm.
habitat: Seaward reefs and shallow lagoons in tropical Indo-Pacific; juveniles prefer staghorn coral reefs; depth range 1–50 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลากะรังมันฝรั่ง
Description: The Potato cod is a large, inquisitive grouper native to Indo-Pacific reefs, including Australia and Southeast Asia. It reaches up to 2.6 m and 110 kg, is patchily distributed, and is considered harmless but may show rare aggression. Listed as Least Concern by IUCN.
Physical Description: Robust, elongated body with irregular dark blotches on pale skin; large mouth; rounded fins; can grow up to 260 cm and 110 kg.
habitat: Reefs across Indo-Pacific from Red Sea to Australia; prefers unfished or protected reef areas; depth 5–150 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาผีเสื้อปากยาวสีเหลือง
Description: The yellow longnose butterflyfish is a small, territorial reef fish found across the Indo-Pacific and eastern Pacific. It forms monogamous pairs, defends coral patches, and uses acoustic signals for communication. Grows up to 22 cm; popular in aquariums.
Physical Description: Bright yellow body, long narrow snout, black face with white spot near mouth; compressed oval shape; dorsal and anal fins elongated; up to 22 cm.
habitat: Coral reefs in tropical Indo-Pacific and eastern Pacific (Africa to Hawaii, Red Sea, Baja California, Galapagos); found at depths of 2–40 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาทูน่าหมาฟัน
Description: Large predatory tuna in Indo-Pacific reefs; apex predator with aggressive behavior; prized game fish; Least Concern.
Physical Description: Streamlined body, blue-green back, silver sides, white belly, two white-tipped dorsal fins; commonly 40–120 cm, max 250 cm.
habitat: Tropical Indo-Pacific reefs; juveniles in shallow areas, adults near drop-offs and seamounts; depth varies widely.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาเพรียงลายหมากรุก
Description: A small wrasse with variable coloration through life stages; protogynous hermaphrodite; Least Concern.
Physical Description: Juveniles are silvery with black-red blotches and eye stripe; adults have a checkerboard scale pattern with pink lines and yellow dorsal spots; up to 27 cm.
habitat: Clear lagoons and seaward reefs, Indo-Pacific (Red Sea to French Polynesia); depth 1–30 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาธงหางยาว
Description: A schooling butterflyfish widespread in the Indo‑Pacific; feeds on zooplankton and occasionally acts as cleaner fish; Least Concern.
Physical Description: Compressed body with extended dorsal filament; white background with two black diagonal bands, yellow fins; max 25 cm, common 15 cm.
habitat: Outer reef slopes and channels across the Indo‑Pacific; depth range 2–178 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาธงหมู่
Description: A schooling butterflyfish widespread in the Indo‑Pacific; feeds on zooplankton and sometimes acts as cleaner fish; Least Concern.
Physical Description: Compressed body with extended dorsal filament; white background with two black diagonal bands, yellow fins; max 21 cm.
habitat: Outer reef slopes and channels, Indo‑Pacific; depth range 5–210 m (commonly 5–30 m).

Thai Fish Name: ปลากะพงตาโต
Description: A reef-associated snapper of the Indo-West Pacific; valued in commercial fisheries; Least Concern.
Physical Description: Silver body with yellow stripe; fusiform shape; max 35 cm.
habitat: Offshore coral reefs and inshore waters; depth range 0–96 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาแฮมป์โนสยูนิคอร์นฟิช
Description: A reef-associated unicornfish across the Indo‑Pacific; feeds on algae and zooplankton; minor commercial importance.
Physical Description: Fusiform, compressed body up to 60 cm; bulbous hump on snout; 5 dorsal spines, 27–30 soft rays.
habitat: Coral reefs, lagoons, estuaries; depth range 2–40 m (commonly 3–20 m).

Thai Fish Name: ปลาสีไฟ
Description: A reef-associated dartfish of the Indian and Pacific Oceans; monogamous and commonly kept in aquaria; Least Concern.
Physical Description: Bright yellow head fading to white body and red-orange tail; long dorsal fin; reaches 9 cm.
habitat: Coral reefs across Indo-Pacific; depth 6–70 m (usually 6–28 m); hovers above substrate.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาหมอทะเล
Description: A vibrant blue surgeonfish with a yellow tail and black palette pattern, found throughout Indo-Pacific coral reefs. Popular in aquariums, it helps maintain coral health by grazing on algae. Grows up to 30 cm; Least Concern.
Physical Description: Royal blue body, yellow tail, black palette design, flat circular shape, pointed snout, small scales; up to 30 cm, ~600 g.
habitat: Coral reefs in Indo-Pacific: Philippines, Indonesia, Japan, Australia, New Caledonia, Samoa, East Africa, Sri Lanka; depth range 2–40 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลากะรังเหยี่ยว
Description: A colorful hawkfish found in Indo-Pacific reefs, often perching on corals and rocks. It has a white body with black sides and red or yellow markings. Grows up to 22 cm and is popular in aquariums and minor fisheries.
Physical Description: White body, black sides, red/yellow markings, robust head, thick lips, perches on corals; up to 22 cm.
habitat: Coral and rocky reefs in Indo-Pacific; perches on corals and rocks; depth range 1–40 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาค้างคาวเทอิรา
Description: A round-bodied batfish of the Indo‑West Pacific, sometimes schooling and entering the aquarium trade; Least Concern.
Physical Description: Circular to triangular compressed body with dark blotches beneath pectoral and above anal fin; changes colour; max length 65–70 cm.
habitat: Juveniles among debris, mangroves, inner reefs; adults on reefs and offshore up to depth of 70 m; schools under Sargassum or shipwrecks.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาหมากขุนทอง
Description: A striking grunt species found in the Indian Ocean and western Pacific. Adults display bold black stripes and yellow fins, while juveniles are mostly black. Inhabits coral and rocky reefs at depths of 2–25 m.
Physical Description: Juveniles are black-striped; adults have black dots on yellow tail. Can reach up to 72 cm in length.
habitat: Coral and rock reefs in Indian Ocean and western Pacific; depth range 2–25 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาหงส์วงแหวน
Description: A large, striking angelfish found in Indo-West Pacific reefs; undergoes dramatic color changes from juvenile to adult; Least Concern.
Physical Description: Deeply compressed body, small mouth; adults dark orange to brown/violet with blue ring near head and blue semicircular marks; juveniles dark blue with turquoise and white vertical stripes; up to 45 cm, usually 30 cm.
habitat: Coastal rocky coral reefs, caves, wrecks; Indo-West Pacific from East Africa to southern Japan, Indonesia, New Guinea, New Caledonia; depth range 3–30 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาหงส์จักรพรรดิ
Description: A striking reef-associated angelfish native to Indo-Pacific oceans; popular among divers and aquarists; Least Concern.
Physical Description: Compressed body with blue/yellow horizontal stripes and dark mask; commonly 30–40 cm, max 40 cm.
habitat: Coral reefs and lagoons; depth range 1–100 m (commonly 3–60 m).

Thai Fish Name: ปลาหงส์หน้ากากเหลือง
Description: A reef-associated angelfish with striking blue-and-yellow face, common across Indo-Pacific lagoons and outer reef slopes; Least Concern.
Physical Description: Compressed body up to 38 cm; blue body with yellow edges forming reticulated pattern; juveniles with vertical bands; large yellow fins edged with blue.
habitat: Coral-rich lagoons and outer reef slopes across Indo-Pacific; depth range 5–30 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาหงส์หลวง
Description: A reef-associated angelfish widely distributed in the Indo-Pacific; often paired, feeds on sponges and tunicates; seldom survives in aquaria.
Physical Description: Compressed, colorful body with alternating blue-white and orange stripes; max length 25 cm.
habitat: Coral-rich lagoons and seaward reefs across Indo-Pacific; depth range 0–110 m, commonly 3–60 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาสไปน์ฟุตลายขีด
Description: A shallow-water herbivorous rabbitfish widespread in the Indo‑Pacific; venomous spines; forms small schools.
Physical Description: Laterally compressed body 25–55 cm (common ~30 cm); bronze-grey with white spots and wavy stripes; venomous dorsal, anal, and pelvic spines.
habitat: Coastal reefs, rocky shores, brackish lagoons and seagrass beds; depths 2–20 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาบาราคูด้าตัวใหญ่
Description: A top predator ray-finned fish found in tropical and subtropical oceans; solitary to schooling behavior; occasionally dangerous to swimmers.
Physical Description: Elongated body, powerful underbite jaw with fanglike teeth; commonly 60–100 cm and 2.5–9 kg, max up to 200 cm and 50 kg; forked tail, two dorsal fins.
habitat: Open seas, coral reefs, mangroves, and seagrasses worldwide in tropical/subtropical waters; depths from surface to 110 m, average daytime ~4 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาบาราคูด้าหางเหลือง
Description: A smaller Indo‑West Pacific barracuda, Lessepsian migrant in the Mediterranean; nocturnal hunter schooling by day.
Physical Description: Elongated body with two separated dorsal fins; yellow‑edged caudal fin; grey dorsally, white underside; common length 40 cm, max 60 cm.
habitat: Reef lagoons and slopes across Indo‑West Pacific and Mediterranean; depth range 2–25 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาบาราคูด้าลายขีด
Description: A schooling predatory fish in Indo-Pacific reefs, named for pickaxe-handle like bars; spawns in Persian Gulf in Oct–Nov.
Physical Description: Slender body with ~20 wavy/oblique bars; underbite jaw; common length ~120 cm, max 150 cm.
habitat: Reef-associated, estuaries, bays, lagoons; Indo-West Pacific from Red Sea to Vanuatu and Tonga.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาบาราคูด้าครีบดำ
Description: A large predatory fish found across the Indo-Pacific region; known for forming large schools near coral reefs.
Physical Description: Slender body with distinctive chevron markings; reaches up to 140 cm; black-tipped fins.
habitat: Coral reefs from the Red Sea and East Africa to French Polynesia; depth range 0–100 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลามัวริชไอดอล
Description: The only extant member of the family Zanclidae, widely distributed across tropical Indo-Pacific reefs; known for its striking appearance and difficulty adapting to captivity.
Physical Description: Disk-like body with black, white, and yellow bands; long tubular snout with bristle-like teeth; sickle-shaped dorsal fin extension; maximum length 23 cm.
habitat: Tropical to subtropical reefs and lagoons; depths from 1 to 182 meters; found from East Africa, Indian Ocean, Pacific Islands to Hawaii and southern Japan.

Thai Fish Name: ปลามังกรจิ๋ว
Description: A small, exotic-looking marine fish in the family Pegasidae, known for shedding its skin in one piece and being used in traditional medicine.
Physical Description: Reaches up to 10 cm; body morphology characteristic of Pegasidae; small size and unusual form.
habitat: Tropical Indo-Pacific waters, including the Red Sea; depths 3–90 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาแมคเคอเรลอินเดีย
Description: A widely distributed coastal pelagic fish in the Indian and western Pacific Oceans; a key species in South and Southeast Asian diets.
Physical Description: Moderately deep body, head longer than body depth; thin dark (golden in fresh) bands on upper body; black spot near pectoral fin; yellowish fins with black-tipped dorsals; max length 35 cm, commonly 25 cm.
habitat: Shallow warm waters of Indian and West Pacific Oceans, from East Africa and Red Sea to Indonesia, China, Ryukyu Islands, Australia, and Samoa; depth range 20–90 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาแตรทะเล
Description: Trumpetfish are long-bodied ambush predators found throughout the tropical western Atlantic. They often swim vertically to blend in with corals and associate with herbivorous fish for cover while hunting.
Physical Description: Slender, tubular body up to 100 cm, with small jaws at the end of a long snout; barbel on chin; variable color (brown, yellow, green, blue-gray); dorsal and anal fins set far back; capable of color change for camouflage.
habitat: Tropical western Atlantic Ocean from Florida to Brazil; depth range 2–25 m.

Thai Fish Name: ปลาหลอกชนิดอร่าม
Description: A camouflaged reef-associated fish found across the Indo-Pacific; females carry eggs in pelvic fin pouch. Least Concern.
Physical Description: Armored, slender body up to 12 cm; tubular snout, elliptic shape; highly color-variable; females ~13 cm, males ~37% smaller.
habitat: Reef edges, seagrass beds and gorgonians from Red Sea to Tonga; depth range 3–35 m (occasionally to 50 m).
